content.body: Luke Warlow: it might be nice to allow for cleaner diffs, but also remember that implementation IDL is allowed to diverge. What's important is that the observable behavior of the APIs matches. Whether that happens through IDL or something else is completely up to the implementation. Now having written that I think it might be better to not allow it as specifications don't really need cleaner diffs or extended attributes all that much.
content.formatted_body: Luke Warlow: it might be nice to allow for cleaner diffs, but also remember that implementation IDL is allowed to diverge. What's important is that the observable behavior of the APIs matches. Whether that happens through IDL or something else is completely up to the implementation. Now having written that I think it might be better to not allow it as specifications don't really need cleaner diffs or extended attributes all that much.

content.body:
I guess my only counter to that is if you're building certain WebIDL tooling (e.g. IDE plugins) you can't rely on the specs grammar to do processing, I know browsers expand the extended attribute list syntax *but* I've yet to find any the permissive grammar didn't account for. Where as with this trailing comma you do have to make a change not in the spec to support it.

Idm too much either way just thought I'd raise query it. I agree it's not going to be useful for actual specification text.
content.formatted_body:
I guess my only counter to that is if you're building certain WebIDL tooling (e.g. IDE plugins) you can't rely on the specs grammar to do processing, I know browsers expand the extended attribute list syntax but I've yet to find any the permissive grammar didn't account for. Where as with this trailing comma you do have to make a change not in the spec to support it.

Idm too much either way just thought I'd raise query it. I agree it's not going to be useful for actual specification text.

content.body: Luke Warlow: I guess I wouldn't mind allowing it, but I'd want specifications to use some sort of canonical style
content.formatted_body: Luke Warlow: I guess I wouldn't mind allowing it, but I'd want specifications to use some sort of canonical style

content.body: Luke Warlow: unrelated, where's type=image in https://drafts.csswg.org/css-forms-1/ ?
content.formatted_body: Luke Warlow: unrelated, where's type=image in https://drafts.csswg.org/css-forms-1/ ?

content.body: Need someone to propose what styles it should get. I don't know the uses of it well enough to meaningfully propose anything (like I said on the issue I'd be just as happy with display: none; ğŸ˜…)
Yeah, maybe it should just say a replaced element like it is today and only get fairly minimal styling.

Like it gets cursor: pointer which surprised me. Maybe we just need to give it that + some of the other very minimal button styles (maybe we can still ensure a minimum size?)

We probably could standardise it's shadow dom to contain an img element that gets it's src and alt set from the input?
Probably the sort of control that will benefit from implementation experience.
If we allow styling the failed load state of an img element I suspect we probably want to do the same for the image input? But maybe not if its barely used in modern sites.
Hey, gang - I'm out on vacation still.  Is anyone available to chair tomorrow's meeting?
